titlestmt.titleproper: A Guide to the William H. Whyte papers FA272

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2020-02-29 00:18:48 -0500.

appraisal.head: Appraisal
appraisal.p: October 1990 (Vol. 162 No. 10) and November 1990 (Vol. 162 No. 11) of House & Garden Magazine were discarded

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Information regarding the Rockefeller Archive Center's preferred elements and forms of citation can be found at http://www.rockarch.org/research/citations.php

separatedmaterial.head: Separated Materials
separatedmaterial.p: Special format items (audio, film, video, digital media, library materials, memorabilia, oversize, and photographic material) have been separated from the file and assigned a unique separation number, as noted. Requests to access open special formats should reference the unique separation number.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The William H. Whyte papers are divided into three series: 1. Projects and Research, 2. Personal, and 3. Audiovisual Materials.
The papers primarily remain in original order, as received.

Whyte grouped his files under various headings or categories, but in many cases the relationship between contents and heading is ambiguous or unapparent. A number of the files also carry whimsical titles, further complicating the task of appraising the contents. In processing Whyte's papers, files have been grouped under his designated headings, with only occasional slight modification of headings or titles for clarity. In a few cases, headings were added to improve order.

In navigating Whyte's papers, it is important to recognize the fluid nature of his categories, titles, and file contents. Materials relating to the same topic may be filed under different headings. For instance, materials relating to the "Street Life Project" are located not only in the Street Life Project section, but also among the Films (General), Lincoln Center, Pedestrian Flows, Plaza Film, Plaza Reports, Plaza Studies, Social Life of the Street, and Vehicular Studies categories, among others. This lack of consolidation, true to the original order of the files, sheds light on Whyte's work process as well as his organizational style.

The distinctions between sections with similar titles are also vague or minor. This is true of the Plaza Report and Plaza Studies headings, as well as the Films (General), Plaza Film, and New Film files. Additionally, some files maintain catch-all headings or headings that were meaningful to Whyte which may not be immediately comprehensible within the given context. Such ambiguity is exemplified by categories such as Books and Films and Grist.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Open for research. Brittle or damaged items are available at the discretion of RAC. Researchers interested in accessing digital media (floppy disks, CDs, DVDs, etc.) or audiovisual material (audio cassettes, VHS, etc.) in this collection must use an access surrogate. The original items may not be accessed because of preservation concerns. To request an access surrogate be made, or if you are unsure if there is an access surrogate, please contact an archivist.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Processed by Laura Quinton (August 2012) and Gail Antos (2014).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The papers of urbanist, journalist, author and people-watcher William H. Whyte, which date from the mid-1940s to the early 1990s, relate primarily to his projects and research. The collection contains a vast amount of material on Whyte's work with easements as well as his various film projects. Materials on studies of pedestrian behavior and city dynamics conducted as part of the "Street Life Project", including Whyte's research on city social life as well as human and vehicular movement patterns, are also a prominent part of the collection.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Projects and Research is by far the largest series, which contains clippings, charts, correspondence, images, graphs, notes and reports related to Whyte's studies.

Within Projects and Research, in addition to individual files, there are several larger categories, including Pedestrian studies, Vehicular studies, Plaza studies, and Easements. There are also specific locations which Whyte studied or about which he was consulted, including Bryant Park, Greenacre Foundation and Park, Lincoln Center, and Penn Station/Madison Square Garden in New York City.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes materials written in French.

did.unittitle: Capitol Land Company: Review of Architects
Report: Study of the Profession of Landscape Architecture
Film, Writing, and Exhibit Promotions: Local Tie-Ins

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Materials concern Whyte's film "City Spaces, Human Places" and his exhibit on Blank Walls, among other topics.

did.unittitle: Reviews of Book and Film Versions of "The Social Life of Small Urban Spaces"
Requests by Individuals and Institutions for Whyte's Films, Television Appearances, and Writings
New York Public Library: Extra Maps
New York Public Library: Use Patterns

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes copies of memos from Whyte to Laurance S. Rockefeller concerning his research on urban spaces and recentralization. Correspondence concerns the New York Landmark Conservancy, and the landmark status of the Ansonia Hotel and Rockefeller Plaza and Channel Gardens. There is no specific reference to Bryant Park.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Personal series contains speeches or outlines of speeches given by Whyte, writings about Whyte, and writings by Whyte. The writings by Whyte include several articles for Fortune magazine and other publications as well as drafts of chapters in a book Whyte hoped to write on his experiences in the Marine Corps in the 1940s.

The Speeches section in this series is also worth noting. Many of the speeches outline and provide insight into Whyte's philosophies and the conclusions he draws as a result of his research. Clippings and articles about Whyte can also be found in the Personal series.

Of particular note, the Personal series actually contains very little information about Whyte's personal life. There are few correspondence files and no journal entries. However, the Writing by Whyte section of this series gives glimpses of Whyte's personality. Manuscripts on the Marine Corps School, which he wrote for an unrealized memoir, contain Whyte's reminiscences on his time in the military. Additionally, Whyte's plays and poems, such as Toffenetti Spaghetti, reveal his creativity and sense of humor.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Files contain speeches, notes, and correspondence relating to speaking engagements.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series 3: Audiovisual Materials consists primarily of slides, and also includes films documenting Whyte's research as well as photographs and slides Whyte used for research, presentations, and projects. This series also contains one file of personal slides, which provide a glimpse of Whyte's life outside of his work, and one file of photographs of Whyte.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: As the mentor for initiatives such as the Project for Public Spaces and the Street Life Project in the 1960's and 1970's, William H. Whyte based his theories about urban planning and social movement on hours of footage and time-lapse photographs.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The collection of edited films held at the RAC come from Whyte's work with the American Conservation Association and his role as an advisor to Laurance Rockefeller. A majority of the Whyte films are unedited trims and original clips, compiled into final films at a later date.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: All inquires to view films require advanced notice of at least 24 hours, and may necessitate notice of up to one week. Individual items, including those not available in modern formats, may be restricted from scholarly access at the discretion of RAC.
When requesting to view films -- please refer to the Title and the AV Number (example: AV 1902).
If the item does not have a designated AV number, please refer to the Title and the Film Number (which consists of a combination of Roman numerals and alphanumerics - example: III 14.1-6).
